Description: Unique and standardized identifier for each Pacific salmon Conservation Unit (CU)
CU Acronym for dashboards
Full offical CU name
Group the CU belongs to, eg. Fraser Sockeye
Data type, either Absolute Abundance (AbsAbd) or Relative Index (RelIdx)
If TRUE the relative abundance metric is calculated (as long as benchmarks are provided)
If TRUE the absolute abundance metric is calculated
If TRUE the short term trend/percent change metric is calculated
If TRUE the long term trend metric is calculated
If TRUE the percentile metric is calculated (currently not used)
Average generation time in years
Does the CU display cyclic abundance patterns (e.g. some Fraser Sockeye CUs like Shuswap_ES)
If the CU is cyclic, which cycle line is dominant
If the CU is cyclic, which cycle line year is dominant (earliest relevant year in the data)
Number of generations used to calculate the percent decline
Provided if additional years of data are used in the percent decline metric
Log-transform data when calculating the percent change metric (TRUE/FALSE)
Use smoothed data when calculating the percent change metric (TRUE/FALSE)
Type of average to use in the long term trend (mean, geometric mean (geomean), median)
Use smoothed data when calculating the long term trend metric (TRUE/FALSE)
Exclude the most recent generation in the long term average component of the long term trend metric (TRUE/FALSE)
Minimum number of years of data needed to calculate the long term trend metric
Use 'regular' or 'smoothed' data when calculating the recent generation average in the relative and absolute abundance metrics. See notes in WSPMetrics package for more details.
Lower benchmark for the relative abundance metric (CU-specific)
Upper benchmark for the relative abundance metric (CU-specific)
Lower benchmark for the absolute abundance metric (1,000)
Lower benchmark for the absolute abundance metric (10,000)
Lower benchmark for the long term trend metric (0.5 converted to 50 in output)
Upper benchmark for the long term trend metric (0.75 converted to 75 in output)
Lower benchmark for the percent change metric (-25%)
Upper benchmark for the percent change metric (-15%)
Not used (NA)
Not used (NA)
Not used (NA)
Not used (NA)
